articles.headline: Security in Afghanistan Is Decaying, U.S. General Says as Forces Leave
articles.snippet: “Civil war is certainly a path that can be visualized,” said Gen. Austin S. Miller, commander of the U.S.-led forces. “That should be a concern for the world.”
articles.abstract: “Civil war is certainly a path that can be visualized,” said Gen. Austin S. Miller, commander of the U.S.-led forces. “That should be a concern for the world.”
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The commander of the U.S.-led mission in Afghanistan warned on Tuesday that the country could be on a path to chaotic civil war as American and other international troops prepare to leave in the coming weeks.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Congress Faces Renewed Pressure to ‘Modernize Our Antitrust Laws’
articles.snippet: After a federal judge threw out state and federal competition cases against Facebook, calls grew for lawmakers to quickly change century-old monopoly laws.
articles.abstract: After a federal judge threw out state and federal competition cases against Facebook, calls grew for lawmakers to quickly change century-old monopoly laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the nation’s antitrust laws were created more than a century ago, they were aimed at taking on industries such as Big Oil.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Jubilant Tigray Capital Greets Insurgents After Ethiopian Retreat
articles.snippet: The capture of the capital, Mekelle, by Tigrayan forces was a major blow to Ethiopia’s leader, eight months into a war that has resulted in widespread famine and one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises.
articles.abstract: The capture of the capital, Mekelle, by Tigrayan forces was a major blow to Ethiopia’s leader, eight months into a war that has resulted in widespread famine and one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEKELLE, Ethiopia — A column of triumphant fighters paraded into the city just after dawn on Tuesday, led by a woman in camouflage who brandished a Kalashnikov and the flag of the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia, while people poured onto the streets to welcome them — cheering, weeping with relief and chanting “Victory is ours!”

articles.headline: ‘We Are Waiting for You’: An Agonizing Vigil for Surfside Families
articles.snippet: Many families have no choice but to navigate an ugly and liminal place where mourning can feel both necessary and premature.
articles.abstract: Many families have no choice but to navigate an ugly and liminal place where mourning can feel both necessary and premature.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURFSIDE, Fla. — All around Magaly Ramsey a chorus of newly familiar strangers were shouting out the names of their loved ones, hoping their voices would penetrate the looming pile of debris. These were the people Ms. Ramsey had spent long days with, waiting for any news of their relatives buried under the fallen building.

articles.headline: Fed Unity Cracks as Inflation Rises and Officials Debate Future
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials are debating what to do as price risks loom, even as its leaders and the White House say today’s surge will most likely cool.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials are debating what to do as price risks loom, even as its leaders and the White House say today’s surge will most likely cool.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials spoke with one voice throughout the pandemic downturn, promising that monetary policy would be set to full-stimulus mode until the crisis was well and truly behind America. Suddenly, they are less in sync.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
